Carbazole-decorated covalent triazine frameworks: Novel nonmetal catalysts for carbon dioxide fixation and oxygen reduction reaction Wenguang Yu Shuai Gu Yu Fu Shaohui Xiong Chunyue Pan Younian Liu Guipeng Yu ⁎ College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hunan Provincial Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Utilization of Manganese Resources, Central South University, Changsha 410083, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Hunan Provincial Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Utilization of Manganese Resources Central South University Changsha 410083 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The task-specific covalent triazine frameworks (CTF-CSUs) with carbazole moieties embedded in the main chain were designed and prepared by a bottom-up technology. The CTF-CSUs exhibit extremely high yields (99%) under significantly mild conditions (0.1 MPa, 25 °C) for CO2 chemical fixation. More importantly, they deliver attractive ORR activity, superior durability and methanol tolerance relative to commercially available Pt/C reference electrocatalyst (E-TEK, 20%). Task-specific carbazole-based covalent triazine frameworks (CTF-CSUs) have been designed and prepared. The obtained materials could serve as excellent catalysts for both CO2 chemical fixation and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Results shown that using CTF-CSUs as catalysts, the cycloaddition reactions between CO2 and epoxides were readily achieved with extremely high yields (99%) under mild conditions (0.1 MPa, 25 °C). The catalysts could be reused for five times without any obvious loss of catalytic activity. In addition, the as-made carbazole-containing CTFs catalysts delivered attractive ORR activity, superior durability and methanol tolerance relative to commercially available Pt/C reference electrocatalyst (E-TEK). Rich N contents (15.33 wt%) and large surface areas (982 m2 g−1) combining abundant mesopores favor a combination of two-electron and four-electron reduction pathway under alkaline condition. All these attracting characteristics were attributed to their unique structures and strong synergistic effect between carbazole and triazine moieties. Keywords Covalent triazine framework Carbazole Oxygen reduction reaction CO2 chemical fixation 1 Introduction Porous organic frameworks, i.e. covalent organic frameworks (COFs) and metal organic frameworks (MOFs), which can atomically allow precise integration of building blocks into crystalline framework networks, are emerged as new platforms for designing high performance materials during the past decade [1–3]. Recently, covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs), which were first developed by Antonietti and Thomas et al. [4] , are arisen as a special kind of crystalline, porous, extended solids starting from commercially available nitriles. Compared to its analogs, CTFs contain higher thermal and chemical stabilities. Owing to their high specific surface area, nitrogen-rich skeleton structure, adjustable pore size, modifiable surface properties and so on [5,6], CTFs have been proved very promising for tremendous application such as gas separation [7], gas storage [8], energy devices [9–11] and heterogeneous catalysis [12–14]. More recently, porous organic polymers (POPs), which represent as one of the fastest developing type of porous materials, have been widely employed as catalysts for CO2 chemical fixation and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Notably, some metal coordinated POPs (e.g. Al, Cr, Co salen-coordinated MOPs [15], PAzo-POP-Ag [16] and Zn@SBMMP [17]) have been approved very promising for CO2 capture and chemical fixation. On the other hand, the metal-incorporated C-COP material has been successfully used as a novel ORR catalyst for fuel cells, which shows the effective electrocatalytic activity of 4e oxygen reduction with excellent stability in alkaline and acidic media [18]. However, the development of metalized polymer materials generally requires specific pre-modification or post-impregnation processes, which demand cumbersome and time-consuming steps to successfully dope a targeted amount of metal [19–21]. In addition, such metal-polymer hybrid catalysts often suffer the loss of metal active sites during the recycling process, which result in the rapid deactivation of catalysts [22]. Moreover, the use of precious metals as catalysts for ORR [23–25] and the requirement of high pressure for CO2 chemical fixation severely limit their popularity in scale-up applications [26]. Hence, it is significant to develop nonmetal catalysts for CO2 chemical fixation and oxygen reduction reaction under mild conditions. The introduction of electron-accepted N atoms into the carbon framework is critical to the ORR because the N atom can increase the positive charge density for its adjacent carbon atoms and weaken the OO bond [27,28]. Therefore, the electrocatalytic activity for ORR could be enhanced by introducing N atoms as active sites. Moreover, N-doped polymer materials have been reported as active catalysts for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction, in which N atoms can serve as CO2-philic sites and catalytic active sites and play crucial roles in the catalytic cycle [29]. In this article, a new class of CTFs with abundant N atoms, more specifically, carbazole-based CTFs (Simplified as CTF-CSUs), which combine the advantages of carbazole and triazine units, was synthesized and investigated as nonmetal catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition and oxygen reduction reaction. The resultant CTF-CSUs were utilized as efficient and reusable heterogeneous catalysts to convert captured CO2 into cyclic carbonates and exhibited high catalytic activity and good recycle stability under mild conditions. Moreover, the as-prepared frameworks showed attractive electrocatalytic activities, high stability and strong methanol tolerance toward oxygen reduction reaction in alkaline media, opening up new avenues to nanostructured polymers for fuel cell, and batteries applications. 2 Experiment section 2.1 Synthesis of CTF-CSUs CTF-CSU1 was synthesized by heating the 3,6-dicyano-9H-carbazole (0.3 g, 1.4 mmol) and ZnCl2 (0.184 g, 1.4 mmol) in a quartz tube. The quartz tube was sealed under vacuum, heated and maintained at a terminal temperature of 400 °C for 48 h. After cooled to room temperature, the resultant mixture was milled, and then sufficiently washed through water, and further stirred in 1 M HCl solution for 12 h to remove the residual metal catalyst. The as-made black powder was filtered and washed successively with water and methanol, then subjected to a further purification including an overnight soxhlet extraction with acetone, methanol and hexane as elution solvent, and finally vacuum-dried at 150 °C. Yield: 93%. Synthesis procedure of CTF-CSU19 was fundamentally same with CTF-CSU1, and a black powder was obtained when substrate was 3,6-dicyano-9-methylcarbazole. Yield: 91%. 2.2 Characterizations FT-IR spectra were collected on a VARIAN 1000 FT-IR (scimitar series) spectrometer. Samples were prepared by dispersing the complexes in KBr and compressing the mixtures to form disks. The crystal structure of each sample was investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD, D/Max2250, Rigaku Corporation, Japan) with nickel-filtered Cu Ka radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), by depositing powder on silicon wafer substrate, from 2θ = 1.5° up to 35° with 0.02° increment. The morphologies and microstructures were probed utilizing Scanning electron microscope (SEM, Nova NanoSEM 230) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI TECNAI G2 F20). Inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) analysis decided quantitatively metal content of the samples on an IRIS Advantage 1000 instrument. CHN analysis was performed on a Vario ELIII CHNOS Elementaranalysator from Elementar Analysensysteme GmbH. The adsorption and desorption isotherms using N2 and CO2 were recorded on an Autosorb-iQ (Quantachrome) analyzer under selected conditions. Low pressure N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms for BET measurements were measured at 77 K. NL-DFT pore size distributions were determined using the carbon/slit-cylindrical pore model of the Quadrawin software. CO2 adsorption isotherms were investigated at two different temperatures of 273 and 298 K from 0 to 1.0 bar. The surface compositions of the materials were studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, K-Alpha 1063, Thermo Fisher Scientific) spectrometer, where the shifts in energy (charging) were calibrated using the C1s peak at 284.6 eV as a reference peak. A PERKIN ELMER TGA7 was utilized to investigate the stability, and the TGA traces were performed at a heating rate of 10 K min−1 under nitrogen atmosphere. The Solid-state 13C CP/MAS (cross-polarization with magic angle spinning) spectra of our samples were obtained through a Bruker Avance III 400 NMR spectrum. The signals were probed at 100.61 MHz at an MASrate of 5.0 kHz using zirconia rotors 4 mm in diameter using a contact time of 3.0 ms and a relaxation delay of 2.0 s. 2.3 Cycloaddition reaction CTF-CSUs catalyst (10 mg), TBAB (1 mmol) and the corresponding epoxide (10 mmol) were added to a 25 mL stainless steel reactor equipped with a magnetic stirring bar and pressure controller. The vessel was pressurized with CO2 (0.1 MPa). After stirring for 48 h at 25 °C, the reaction mixture was filtered off and washed with CH2Cl2 to ensure complete removal of the product and any unreacted starting materials from the pores of the CTF-CSUs organocatalyst. The filtrate was concentrated and the crude samples were analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy. To measure the recyclability, the separated powder catalyst was continuously recovered by centrifugation, washing with dichloromethane, desiccation. Finally, the catalyst was used again for the subsequent cycle operation with fresh reactants under the same reaction conditions. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements Electrochemical tests (including CV, chronoamperometry and LSV) were recorded on a Zahner electrochemical analyzer with a rotating disk electrode (RDE). All electrochemical ORR measurements were performed on a normal three-electrode system and Ag/AgCl/3 M KCl electrode as a reference electrode. All the potential of this work had been transformed into a reversible hydrogen electrode RHE (see supporting information). 0.1 M KOH solution was used as electrolyte in the process of electrochemical measurements, which deaerated by high purity O2 (99.99% pure) according to the concrete conditions. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) experiments were recorded from 0 to 1.2 V (vs. RHE), and the scan rate was 50 mV s−1. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) experiments were performed from 0 to 1.2 V (vs. RHE) at 5 mV s−1 under rotating speeds varying from 400 to 1600 rpm. The current densities were obtained without background current subtracted. The ORR onset potential E onset is defined as the potential at the intersection of the tangent lines before and after the disk current rise in the RDELSV curve. The ORR stability performance was tested by the current–time (i-t) chronoamperometric responses at 1.67 V (vs. RHE) for 12,000 s. Methanol crossover was performed by adding 3 M methanol at 300 s in response to i-t at 0.67 V (vs. RHE). Koutechy-Levich (K-L) Eqs. (1–3) is used to calculate the current density and the number of transferred electrons (n): (1) 1 J = 1 J K + 1 B ω 1 / 2 (2) B = 0.2 n F D 0 2 / 3 υ - 1 / 6 C 0 (3) J K = nFk C 0 Jk and J are the kinetic current density and the measured current density, respectively. D 0 is the diffusion coefficient of O2 (1.9 * 10−5 cm2 s−1), C 0 is the concentration of O2 (1.2 * 10−6 mol cm−3), v is the kinetic viscosity (0.01 cm2 s−1), F is the Faraday constant (96,485 C mol−1) and ω is the electrode rotation speed. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Synthesis, characterization and properties of CTF-CSUs Carbazole-based covalent triazine frameworks (CTF-CSUs) were synthesized starting from the pre-designable carbazole-based nitrile precursors via a bottom-up technology. Two precursors containing carbazole moieties, i.e. 3,6-dicyanocarbazole and 3,6-dicyano-9-methylcarbazole, were designed and prepared through one-step procedure and two-step procedure, respectively, starting from commercially available 3,6-dibromocarbazole (S1). The frameworks were obtained under ionothermal polymerization of 3,6-dicyanocarbazole or its derivative in the catalysis of molten ZnCl2. Under carefully selected polymerization conditions, we attempted to obtain two kinds porous crystalline frameworks with an assumed long-range assumed structure (Scheme 1 ). After polymerization, black monoliths were readily obtained, and the CTF-CSUs were collected as black powders after sufficient grinding and intense washing to remove the trapped catalyst ZnCl2. The polymerization yields were typically exceeding 90% suggesting that the unexpected side-reactions were suppressed during the polymerization. In case of CTF-CSU1, trace amount of residual zinc chloride was detected by EDS spectrum (Fig. S1a), while for CTF-CSU19, the salt was removed almost completely (Fig. S1b). The contents of the zinc in CTF-CSUs were further determined by ICP-AES on the samples after fully degraded in nitrohydrochloric acid. The ICP-AES results show relatively low zinc contents around 0.025 at% for CTF-CSU1 and 0.002 at% for CTF-CSU19, respectively, which are also in good agreement with EDS analysis. The successful preparation of the carbazole-based covalent triazine frameworks was demonstrated by FT-IR analysis (Fig. S2). The disappearance of carbo-nitrile band at 2228 cm−1 indicates the success of a trimerization reaction, while the appearance of absorption band at 1628 cm−1 proves the generation of s-triazine ring. Meanwhile, the structural completeness of CTF-CSU19 was proved by CP/MAS 13C NMR (Fig. S3). The extensive chemical shifts in the region between 110 and 140 ppm are related to the aromatic carbon atoms of the framework. The peaks locate at 25 ppm and 175 ppm, which are attributed to the methyl carbons and the carbon cores of s-triazine, respectively. The obtained polymer samples both demonstrate excellent chemical resistance toward common organic solvents, such as acetone, dimethyl sulfoxide, N, N-dimethylformamide and tetrahydrofuran, and also acid or base, typically, they are insoluble in the dilute HCl or NaOH solution. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves under N2 and air atmosphere (Fig. S4) reveal that the polymers are thermally stable up to 400 °C (5% weight loss), which meet the demand for applications in CO2 uptake and heterogeneous catalysis. A slight weight loss below 200 °C could be mainly associated with the solvent molecules trapped in the pores. To characterize the pore properties and surface area of the CTF-CSUs, adsorption–desorption measurements were carried out at 77 K using nitrogen as a probe. The rapid uptake at a relatively low pressure (<0.01) indicates our materials are microporous (Fig. 1 a). With the increasing pressure, the nitrogen uptake increases slightly implied the presence of mesopores and interparticular voids in the materials. The specific surface areas are obtained at 685 m2 g−1 for CTF-CSU1, and 982 m2 g−1 for CTF-CSU19, respectively, by applying the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) model. Our CTF-CSUs are at least partial crystalline as revealed by X-ray diffraction experiments. The XRD pattern (Fig. S5) reveals some strong reflection peaks for CTF-CSU1. This indicates the formation of a crystalline triazine organic framework with similar triangular filler pores (Scheme 1). A broad peak is found at 26.17, which corresponds to an interlayer distance of 3.43 Å for the (0 0 1) aromatic sheets, and another intense peak at smaller angles (7.13) corresponds to the (1 0 0) reflections and two additional weak peaks at 10.23 and 12.08 could be assigned to (1 1 0) and (2 0 0) reflections, respectively. Based on these primary results, a geometry optimization of a section of the sheets was carried out, where the distance of the (0 0 1) peak from XRD is used for the interlayer distance between the sheets (c = 3.43 Å). The resulting periodicity is used to assemble the hexagonal cell, and fortunately each layer of atoms placed in the next layer of P6/mmm symmetric analog of the AAA structure was found very close to our experimental structure (Fig. S5). The assumed structure from the geometrically optimized CTF-CSU1 as well as a careful comparison with the XRD pattern is shown in Scheme 1. However, it should be noted that the widening of the diffraction peak and the existence of many other signals may point to a limited long-range sequence. Demonstrated in the SEM images are the aggregates of uniform and dense microgel particles with dimensions of 100–200 nm for the CTF-CSUs (Fig. 2 ). To further explore the morphology and crystalline information of CTF-CSUs catalysts, high resolution TEM (HR-TEM) was presented (Fig. 3 ). Alternately, a dark and bright area implies the rich porous structures of the CTF-CSUs. The clear fringes observed in Fig. 3b indicate the crystallinity of the synthesized nanoparticles, in spite of the presence of numerous defects, consistent with XRD data (Fig. S5). To attest the chemical composition of our CTF-CSUs, high-resolution XPS data collected for the synthesized samples confirm the presence of carbon, nitrogen and oxygen (Fig. S6). Deconvoluted N 1s spectra display three main contributions (Fig. 4 ), whereas the signals at 400.6–400.7, 399.8–400.0 and 398.5–398.6 eV correspond to graphitic N, carbazole N or pyrrolic N and triazine N or pyridinic N, respectively, which partly relies on assignments reported in the literature for CTF-10 [30a], but it is hard to distinguish the peak assignment, due to partially carbonized of the samples. These results clearly indicate that the particles of the resulting CTF-CSUs contain a significant amount of nitrogen atoms which are linked with both the five and six-membered aromatic rings [30b]. The XPS results also show relatively low zinc contents around 0.286 at% for CTF-CSU1 and no residual zinc chloride for CTF-CSU19, respectively, which are also in good agreement with ICP-AES analysis. The EDS mapping of CTF-CSU1 (Fig. 2a) suggests that the nitrogen atom is distributed homogenous throughout the framework. Elemental analysis (Table S1) of CTF-CSU1 gives a lower nitrogen content (15.33 wt%) than the theoretically calculated values, while compared to CTF-CSU1, a much lower content of nitrogen atom (9.32 wt%) is detected for CTF-CSU19. This indicates that a part of the nitrogen is lost during polymerization due to decomposition[30a]. 3.2 CTF-CSUs catalyzed CO2 fixation under mild conditions Given large surface areas and high nitrogen content, CTF-CSU19 demonstrates a good CO2 uptake capacity (Table S2, 12.9 wt%, 273 K and 1 bar), while CTF-CSU1 delivers a higher CO2 uptake capacity to 15.1 wt% under same conditions (Fig. S8). It would be reasonable considering the evenly and densely dispersed carbazole and triazine that significantly promote the matrix-CO2 interaction [31]. High CO2 uptakes together with the densely exposed and accessible triazine and carbazole catalytic sites within the framework of CTF-CSUs motivated us to explore their catalytic activities for CO2 cycloaddition reaction. As expected, our CTF-CSUs feature remarkably high catalytic activities in the conversion of epoxides to the corresponding cyclic carbonates under mild conditions (Table 1 , Table S3). The plot in Fig. 5 a relates the yield of the targeted product (4-(bromomethyl)-1,3-dioxolan-2-one) to reaction time under 0.1 MPa and at 25 °C. Obviously, the catalytic activity of CTF-CSU19 is higher than CTF-CSU1, which may be due to the increase in surface area and pore volume when the starting compound 3,6-dibromo-9H-carbazole was electrophilically substituted in the 9H position by methyl. Moreover, the plot further revealed that the optimum reaction time for the coupling of CO2 with epoxides is 48 h. Remarkably, CTF-CSU19 performed with high efficiency in the CO2 cycloaddition especially with small-sized epoxides (entries 1–4): the propylene oxide was converted to propylene carbonate with a high yield (99%) within 48 h. A slightly decrease in the yield (96%) was observed when the hydrogen of the substrate was substituted for a bromine or chlorine, and such values are extremely effective, as the yields are still far higher than most known MOF catalysts under same conditions [32]. The high catalytic activity of the framework catalysts should be ascribed to the increase in the CO2 affinity via the introduction of nitrogen-rich carbazole and triazine groups into the framework. To check the generality of the CO2 cycloaddition in this work, large epoxides were also probed as substrates and the experiments were performed under identical conditions (entries 4–7). With the increase in the length of the alkyl chain, the activity of the catalyst does not decrease significantly (entries 4–5). However, compared with small substrates, there is a certain decrease in yields for the substrates that contain large-size substituents like benzene ring (entries 6–7). It is clear that large substrates cannot diffuse easily into the channels for catalyzed reactions. These observations also indicate that the transformations of small substrates with CO2 have been carried out within our frameworks rather than the outside of pores. Another possible reason would be the strong pi-pi effect between benzene ring and the catalyst skeleton, which leads to the occurrence of dimerization of the cyclic carbonate and hydrolysis and isomerization of the epoxide during the reaction [33]. Nevertheless, it remains unclear that how these side reactions are promoted through these special epoxides. Notably, the as-made frameworks exhibit the size selectivity to small and large substrates in the investigated reactions. The propylene oxide/CO2 coupling reaction catalyzed by co-catalyst TBAB yields only 50% propylene carbonate after 48 h with the absence of catalysts. However, catalysts mixtures that combining trace mount of CTF-CSU1 or CTF-CSU19 with a co-catalyst TBAB have promoted the coupling reaction with a significantly high yield (83% or 99%) under mild conditions (Compared to the blank experiment (i.e., without co-catalyst; 1% conversion of propylene oxide)), which indicates that there is a strong synergistic effect between the CTF-CSUs and TBAB. This is notably better than the 78% yield already reported for the homogeneous catalyst Salen-Co-OAc [34]. The high density of the triazine and carbazole units that are located in the pore structures of the CO2-capturing heterogeneous catalyst would attribute to the enhanced performance of our CTF-CSUs compared with Salen-Co-OAc. Compared with other metal-free heterogeneous catalysts (Table S4), CTF-CSU19 performed with higher efficiency in the CO2 cycloaddition under mild conditions (0.1 MPa, 25 °C) in a desired time (48 h). The slight mesoporosity and comparable high BET surface areas of CTF-CSU19 are beneficial to the contact between reactants and catalytic activity sites. Mesoporous structures are particularly desirable because of the promoted mass transfer of reactants [35]. As shown in Table 2 , our CTF-CSUs show comparable activity compared to crystalline CTF-0 (entry 5 vs entry 1) while deliver higher activity than crystalline CTF-1 (entry 5 vs entry 2) under lower pressure and temperature. In our cases, the pore size could be a significant factor. Here, the small micropores can enrich CO2, but do not allow the easy diffusion of larger substrates like epichlorohydrin. In fact, the catalytic activity of CTF-CSU19 appears to be significantly higher than CTF-CSU1, due to its higher surface area and larger pore size (Fig. 1b), and the product yield is sufficiently high (96%) after 48 h (entry 5 vs entry 4). This trend is in good agreement with the comparison of known samples like CTF-1 and CTF-1-HSA (entry 2 vs entry 3), where the presence of an additional low percentage of mesopores proves to be very beneficial for this transformation. It is noteworthy that CTF-CSU19 can catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides bearing small-sized substituents under atmospheric pressure and room temperature, and the reaction of the propylene oxide substrate features the best yield (99%). According to previously reported mechanisms for the cycloaddition reactions of CO2 and epoxides [36], a proposed general mechanism is illustrated. Scheme S1 shows the cycloaddition of CO2 and PO with TBAB as nucleophilic reagent. PO is activated by triazine/carbazole (1), then attacked by the nucleophilic reagent (represent as 2) affording a zwitter ion (3) with an anion located at the oxygen (Oe) and a positive charge delocalized at the triazine ring. Then, the Oe rapidly attacks the carbon of CO2 to generate another zwitter ion (4) with a carbonate moiety. The carbonate intermediate (4) is capable of cyclization followed by the nucleophilic reagent leaving to form PC with the regeneration of the CTF-CSUs. To test the catalyst reusability, the reaction of epibromohydrin with CO2 catalyzed by CTF-CSUs/TBAB was taken as an example. The catalysts were recovered through centrifugation, washing with dichloromethane, desiccation and then used directly for the next run without any further purification. In each run, as shown in Fig. 5b, the yield of the targeted compound 4-(bromomethyl)-1,3-dioxolan-2-one delivers only slightly change even after five runs. The carbazole-based CTFs exhibit excellent repeatability and stability in cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides. These results manifest the potential aspect of carbazole-based CTF-CSUs for capture and conversion of CO2 into valuable products under mild conditions, thus utilizing CO2 as an environmentally friendly and renewable C1 structural unit. 3.3 CTF-CSUs catalyzed oxygen reduction reaction The highly open surface area and a robust porous structure CTF-CSUs enable the them as ideal catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), which proved to be of great importance for fuel cells [37]. Moreover, pyridinic nitrogen and graphitic nitrogen are perceived as the active center for ORR [38]. To demonstrate the application of the as-prepared CTF-CSUs, ORR catalytic activities of the samples were first probed by CV measurements in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. In Fig. 6 a, both CTF-CSUs samples show well-defined cathodic ORR peaks in aqueous solution of KOH (0.1 M) saturated with O2, but not N2, within the potential range from 0 to 1.2 V. The CV curve of CTF-CSU1 exhibits a higher peak current and a more positive ORR peak potential than CTF-CSU19, proving the lower overpotential of the former toward ORR and its higher catalytic activity. For further investigating the ORR performance of the samples, the LSV curves were obtained by carrying out RDE tests. To emphasize the value of the samples, the commercial Pt/C catalyst (E-TEK, 20%) as a reference was measured. As shown in Fig. 6b, CTF-CSU1 exhibits an E onset of 0.79 V, which is much higher than CTF-CSU19. The prominent ORR activities for CTF-CSU1 are also confirmed by its positive half-wave potential E 1/2 (0.57 V) and large current density (5.6 mA cm−2). Furthermore, the electrocatalytic performances of our samples are comparable with other known metal-free electrocatalysts previously reported (Table S5). Remarkably, CTF-CSU1 exhibits a larger limited current density than the commercial Pt/C catalyst (5.03 mA cm−2), despite its slightly negative half-wave potential and the onset potential. The large limited current density of CTF-CSU1 may be due to broad diffusion pathways for the solvated O2 on these carbazole-based CTFs samples with high nitrogen content. The carbazole-NH embedded within the triazine framework can probably further increase the number of active sites, leading to the break of OO bonds of oxygen molecules. RDE measurements with various rotating speeds in an O2-saturated system at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 are performed. The Koutecky-Levich (K-L) equations are applied to study the kinetic parameters (Fig. 6c, e), where the linear representation of the K-L graphs shows the first order kinetics of the electron transfer number (n) at various potentials [39]. On the basis of the line slopes, two n value of 2.4 to 2.6 were obtained within 0.2–0.5 V (vs RHE) under alkaline conditions, indicating that the ORR at CTF-CSUs is a combination of two-electron and four-electron reactions (Fig. 6d, f). This result implies that the catalysis process in this case is similar to that of G-g-C3N4 and N-doped carbon nanotube cups [40,41]. This can be attributed to the unique carbazole and triazine modified porous structure, which are beneficial to the fast diffusion of O2 in electrolyte for ORR. The stability and methanol tolerance of the catalysts are also significant for practical applications. Therefore, the stability of our CTF-CSUs was first evaluated by the current-time (i-t) chronoamperometric responses, compared against the commercial Pt/C catalyst [42,43]. In Fig. 7 a, the CTF-CSUs exhibit a very slow attenuation and a high relative current of 92% and 87% is retained after 12,000 s in alkaline solution. In contrast, the ORR current on Pt/C declines sharply in alkaline solutions as measured under the same conditions. The CTF-CSUs show a stable current-time (i-t) chronoamperometric response after the introduction of 3.0 M methanol in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution (Fig. 7b). It is clear that our CTF-CSUs deliver much better stability and improved methanol tolerance for ORR relative to the commercial Pt/C catalyst. This may be ascribed to the nonmetal chemical composition and high thermo-chemical stability of our frameworks, and more importantly, the latter effectively prevents the loss of catalytic activity for ORR. Therefore, the facilely prepared carbazole-based CTFs catalyst exhibited attractive ORR activity, better durability and methanol tolerance than commercial Pt/C catalyst, further revealing its great potential for application in ORR catalysis. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have developed a new bifunctional catalysis system via simply introducing carbazole moiety into covalent triazine frameworks by bottom-up chemistry. More importantly, the frameworks are featured by large surface area, high nitrogen content and excellent physico-chemical stability. Such an intrinsic structure feature gives it with wonderful heterogeneous catalytic activity for CO2 chemical fixation under mild conditions, which can be readily recycled. Meanwhile, the resulting CTFs exhibit attractive ORR activity, while delivering stronger tolerance to methanol crossover and better durability with the commercial Pt/C catalyst, further revealing its great potential for application in ORR catalysis. The carbazole-based CTFs in this work are expected to underpin future research efforts to develop preponderant materials for conversion of CO2 into value-added products, high performance electrocatalysts for ORR and other applications, and also to provide commendable opportunities to researching the molecular mechanism of heterogeneous catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Task-specific carbazole-based covalent triazine frameworks (CTF-CSUs) have been designed and prepared. The obtained materials could serve as excellent catalysts for both CO2 chemical fixation and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Results shown that using CTF-CSUs as catalysts, the cycloaddition reactions between CO2 and epoxides were readily achieved with extremely high yields (99%) under mild conditions (0.1 MPa, 25 °C). The catalysts could be reused for five times without any obvious loss of catalytic activity. In addition, the as-made carbazole-containing CTFs catalysts delivered attractive ORR activity, superior durability and methanol tolerance relative to commercially available Pt/C reference electrocatalyst (E-TEK). Rich N contents (15.33 wt%) and large surface areas (982 m2 g−1) combining abundant mesopores favor a combination of two-electron and four-electron reduction pathway under alkaline condition. All these attracting characteristics were attributed to their unique structures and strong synergistic effect between carbazole and triazine moieties.
coredata.dc:title: Carbazole-decorated covalent triazine frameworks: Novel nonmetal catalysts for carbon dioxide fixation and oxygen reduction reaction
